physDesc.p: Four pages typewritten in black ink. Address given for H. D. in the top left corner of the first page: Mrs. Richard Aldington Mrs. Richard Aldington ‘Leven Oaks Hotel Monrovia California. On the first page, the date was originally given as 13 January 20; "20" was crossed out in pencil, and "21" was written in its place. Subsequent pages read "13 January 21." Unsigned.

editorialDecl.p: This letter contains references to the following:

body.p: Thank you very much for your letter of December 22nd. I should have answered it sooner, but really, my dear, you can understand how difficult it is to catch up with things, I have been ill so long; and then Houghton Mifflin insist upon my legend book coming out in April, which means that the manuscript must be in in March, and one of the legends which I have been mulling over during my illness suddenly came to a head and had to be written and I had to drop everything and get at it. It is queerer than Dick’s hat-band, but I think it will make a good contrast to the others.

Then Yale, who has never smiled either upon new poets or upon women, was suddenly seized with a desire to have me come down there and give one of the lectures of the Francis Bergen Foundation. This time it is to be on the centenary of Keats’s death, and means a lecture on Keats; and as a kind of bonne bouche, to make up for asking me to talk on some other poet, they have added a reading of my own poems at the Elizabethan Club the day before. As Yale is the only one of the larger colleges at which I have not yet spoken, and as they are so sadly in need of a little proselytizing, I thought I had better do it. Luckily, I have finished my legend, or virtually so; and therefore I am able to start on the Keats lecture; but all this coming so soon after my operation has put rather a strain upon me, and my mail has got jiggled off into a corner, perforce.

Please tell Winifred that I shall write to her in a day or two, but as your letter precedes those of hers which I have not answered, I feel that you come first on the list this time. Please tell her that I delight in her letters; they have been the brightest star of my illness. She is such a good and faithful correspondent.

Now, my dear, I have some news for you. Mr. Holliday of Henry Holt & Company wrote most enthusiastically welcoming my suggestion that they look over the manuscript of your book, "Hymen," with a view to publication. I told them all about Monro, but they were willing to read the volume as it was, and I sent it to them at once. I have not heard anything as yet, but I suppose I shall soon, and I will let you know as soon as I do. I have told them that they would have to make arrangements through Monro as he owns the copyright, but it is possible that he is not copyrighting it in America, in which case of course it cannot be copyrighted here as it would not be able to come out simultaneously with the English edition. I do not think that matters much, as it is not like a best seller novel. Lots of English books here are published here that are not copyrighted. There the matter is at present, and I will let you or Winifred know as soon as a new phase opens.

Winifred’s accounts of your adventures with your nurse fill me with joy. That woman is as good as a penny dreadful all by herself, and I am afraid you young things do not hold a strong enough hand over her. English servants always have to be held down very tightly. They get out of hand if they are allowed the least leeway, at least that is the experience of an old housekeeper. I have been keeping house for twenty years with various nationalities, and I could write a book on the different ways each has to be treated. What between the nurse and the chauffeur when you went to San Diego I must say you are having an exciting time. What I do regret is that we are no nearer together. It would be such fun to be able to talk. Now that I am getting back to normal again, I feel very much in need of a good talk.

Winifred says that you want to know somewhere to spend the Summer, but of course you must realize that there are so many places that one cannot give you any advice. What between East, and West, and mountains, and seas, you have a variety of choice which is simply bewildering. I think if I wanted the sea, I should take the Maine coast, if I were you. If you wanted sea bathing, I should try the Cape – Cape Cod, that is – or Long Island. If you want mountains or woods, there is all of New Hampshire and much of Maine. Peterborough has the MacDowell Colony of artists and is a lovely country. There are lots of places that are not over-fashionable, plenty, I think, of the type you want; but what grieves me is that I shall be in none of them. I hope to get over to England this Spring, but the doctor seems to think that May is too soon for me to attempt a sea voyage, and I think June would be too late, which would put my going off until the Autumn. I distinctly do not want that as I am afraid of the English cold in the Autumn. At present I am merely getting well and doing my work.

I have another month quietly here, and then I start to New York to lecture at the Brooklyn Institute of Arts and Sciences; from there to Yale for my two lectures, and back again to New York for a lecture at Columbia. Then I come home for a brief space, and dash off for a University Extension Society lecture in Philadelphia; and somewhere in the offing, Brown University, Dartmouth, and Smith College, with a plethora of proof stuck into the interstices, and, I hope, another legend which cries to be written down. You see there is not much time, and I think for a lady who has had two operations in eight months, it is not perhaps a bad record.

Winifred suggests that your book of Greek essays be submitted to Ferris Greenslet to take abroad with him, but it would be too late for that just now as he sails almost immediately; but I would not hurry it, just let it simmer and digest, and next year will be quite as good as this year for its publication. Art is long, and the more I see of things, the more I am convinced that it is a mistake to hurry anything; and the farther away we get from the war, the better will be the selling possibilities, I think. The sales market has been completely knocked out in the general slump of business lately, and the publishers are looking very unhappy, so I really think that some months hence would be a better time to submit any manuscripts you have than the present would be.

If Holt does take this book of yours, they are a very good firm and much interested in modern poetry, more interested, I think, than Houghton Mifflin. In fact, I am inclined to think that if I were not with Houghton Mifflin, I should be with Holt. With me, it is scarcely a matter of choice as Ferris Greenslet is such an old and tired friend of mine, but Holt has got younger and more energetic blood in the firm, and if this book is published by them, I do not know why they would not make a good firm to continue to publish your American editions. However, we can decide that later when you have a volume ready.

I cannot write any more now as I have a perfect stack of letters to answer, but this takes lots of love from Mrs. Russell and me to you both, and most kind rememberances to your mother. Winifred’s picture of Perdita and her Christmas Presents, which came this morning, is absolutely delightful. What a healthy looking little creature she is! Tell Winifred to take some snap shots of you and herself, and send them to me.
